issues.title: Is super-jumbo appropriate?
issues.author: tuexen
issues.body:
I'm wondering if using super-jumbo as an indication to increase the upper limit is too striking, since either super or jumbo would provide the information.
What about using "Large Record Sizes for (D)TLS"? Since the document will specify a flags extension to be used in combination with the record size limit extension to negotiate a record size limit larger than the currently protocol-defined record size limit, I don't think describing the contents as "an extension" or as an "flags extension" covers it. Maybe we should also not limit this in the title to 1.3, since it might also work in future versions of the protocol.

comments.author: emanjon
comments.body:
>What about using "Large Record Sizes for (D)TLS"
>Maybe we should also not limit this in the title to 1.3
Sounds good to me. That is definitely a more appropriate name. TLS WG used to put 1.3 in titles, but I note the last RFC has title "Delegated Credentials for TLS and DTLS"

comments.author: emanjon
comments.body: The orignal draft was written for 1.2 and 1.3. With the flag extension this would be 1.3 only. I will remove all mention of 1.2

issues.title: Removal of PMTU related text?
issues.author: tuexen
issues.body: I'm wondering if the last paragraph in Section 3 is needed in this document. It is pretty much the same as in RFC 8449. This document only specifies a flag allowing to use the extension defined in RFC 8449 in a more general way. So everything saig]d in RFC 8449 applies. So I suggesting to remove the paragraph... Any opinion?

comments.author: emanjon
comments.body: Sound good to me. It made sense when the extension was used independently of RFC 8449. Can/Should be removed now.

issues.title: Recommended: Y?
issues.author: tuexen
issues.body:
I'm not sure if
```
Recommended: Y
```
is the correct choice. I also haven found the text in an RFC describing that line. However, I think that the flags extension we define is only needed in some scenarios. So is the above the appropriate choice?

comments.author: emanjon
comments.body:
The soon to be adopted definition of the "Recommended" Column is in 
https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-ietf-tls-rfc8447bis/

Y just means it is RECOMMENDED for the specified purpose, which might be limited.

```
3.  Adding "Recommended" Column

   The instructions in this document update the Recommended column,
   originally added in [RFC8447] to add a third value, "D", indicating
   that a value is "Discouraged".  The permitted values are:

   Y:  Indicates that the IETF has consensus that the item is
      RECOMMENDED.  This only means that the associated mechanism is fit
      for the purpose for which it was defined.  Careful reading of the
      documentation for the mechanism is necessary to understand the
      applicability of that mechanism.  The IETF could recommend
      mechanisms that have limited applicability, but will provide
      applicability statements that describe any limitations of the
      mechanism or necessary constraints on its use.

   N:  Indicates that the item has not been evaluated by the IETF and
      that the IETF has made no statement about the suitability of the
      associated mechanism.  This does not necessarily mean that the
      mechanism is flawed, only that no consensus exists.  The IETF
      might have consensus to leave an items marked as "N" on the basis
      of it having limited applicability or usage constraints.

   D:  Indicates that the item is discouraged.  This marking could be
      used to identify mechanisms that might result in problems if they
      are used, such as a weak cryptographic algorithm or a mechanism
      that might cause interoperability problems in deployment.
      Implementers SHOULD consult the linked references associated with
      the item to determine the conditions under which it SHOULD NOT or
      MUST NOT be used.

   Setting a value to "Y" or "D" in the "Recommended" column requires
   IETF Standards Action [RFC8126].  Any state transition to or from a
   "Y" or "D" value requires IESG Approval.  Not all items defined in
   Standards Track RFCs need to be set to "Y" or "D".  Any item not
   otherwise specified is set to "N".  The column is blank for values
   that are unassigned or reserved unless specifically set.
```

comments.author: emanjon
comments.body: So my interpretation is that Y is OK/Correct.

comments.author: tuexen
comments.body: I agree. Thank you very much for providing a pointer to the description of the column.

issues.title: RFC 8449 negotiates plaintext length, not ciphertext
issues.author: emanjon
issues.body:
Ben Kaduk wrote:

I also note that the semantics of record_size_limit per RFC 8449 are to
apply to the plaintext length, so I think it actually is weird and
overly complicated for your draft to propose that the negotiated length
will now be of the ciphertext length.

pulls.title: Limit the maximum plaintext record size to 2^16-257
pulls.author: tuexen
pulls.body: This results in a maximum ciphertext record size of 2^16-257+255+1, which is 2^16-1. This is the largest value, which can be encoded in a 16 bit length field.
